awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Radar Snow Retrieval
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will develop transformative, machine-learning algorithms that will improve water management. Water management is critically important to the social well-being, food supply, and climate resiliency of the local population in the Western United States, yet water managers lack adequate snowpack depth and water content information necessary for the management, storage, and transfer of water for irrigation and consumption. Water deficits are made worse when snowpack depths are in error, potentially resulting in devastating damage to agricultural economies and vulnerable populations. The proposed technology will be able to scale from storm events to seasonal snowpack estimations and provide accurate mappings of snowpack depths and water equivalents for watershed areas needing water management.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project develops algorithms for determining snowpack depth and water content. Snow retrieval algorithm development has not kept pace with the deployment of short wavelengths.  C- and X-band radars are used as ‘gap-filling’ radars in mountainous valleys. Developing effective algorithms for detection of snow water equivalent is needed for these short wavelength radars. Artificial Intelligence/Machine Learning (AI/ML) and optimization algorithms are expected to improve estimation accuracy compared with point-scale (sensor) observations and across watershed areas relevant to water management. Physics-guided neural networks (PGNNs) can produce physically consistent results and generalize to out of sample scenarios. Application of a PGNN to snow retrievals is expected to perform better than purely data-driven or deterministic algorithms. Anticipated technical results will provide water managers with a cloud-based subscription service updated in real-time, using historical and current radar data to improve operational decision-making.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project lies in developing a feasible method and commercialization plan for weather radar-based snowpack monitoring. Understanding the water stored as snowpack in mountains is crucial for forecasting snowmelt and downstream water availability. The escalating demands on water resources, driven by consumption and population growth, are exacerbated by climate change, leading to a pressing water crisis. With snowpack becoming more extreme and variable, there is a critical need for advanced technology to enhance its estimation accuracy. This project successfully showcases the viability of a novel method that reduces uncertainties in snowpack measurement, introducing a cutting-edge monitoring approach using weather radar to ensure more reliable water resource management.

We demonstrated the technical viability of our approach by accurately estimating snowpack with an accuracy meeting water managers’ need. Snowfall estimation by radar with an accuracy better than 10% will assist water managers in making informed decisions about water management to conserve water supply and mitigate flood risk. Our commercialization plan involved collecting market intelligence, identifying a beachhead market, and conducting interviews and surveys with over 100 potential stakeholders. The outcome indicates a strong demand in the marketplace for new technology.

The technology developed not only advances scientific understanding but also benefits underserved populations in areas where crop yields rely on snowmelt for irrigation. Improved snowpack estimation enhances water supply predictions and aids in preventing flood-related losses. This information also benefits municipal water supply planning, hydroelectric utility operations, avalanche risk assessment, among others. The resulting patent-pending technology, SnowQ™, utilizes weather radar-based monitoring of snowpack, integrating physics-informed machine learning and remote-sensing data for improved accuracy and dynamic snowpack quantification. This achievement enhances the technological leadership and competitiveness of the United States.

 

 


Last Modified: 03/01/2024
Modified by: Baxter Vieux
